Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Updating to the latest servercommon" (#9533) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Bringing in the lates changes from ServerCommon.

### Impact

I'm unable to use NuGet.org

### Describe the bug

I am not able to upload a generated snupkg to Nuget.org. During indexing it always reports this error "The uploaded symbols package contains one or more pdbs that are not portable."

The snupkg in question contains a .NET assembly with a portable PDB (file starts with "BSJB"), but also a C++ component and its pdb. I suspect the portability-validation fails for the C++ pdb (starting with `Microsoft C/C++ MSF 7.00`), but there is nothing I can do here, since as far as I know, the portable-pdb format is a concept for .NET assemblies only.

### Repro Steps

1. Ship snupkg with valid pdb from .NET assembly, and PDB from generated by MSVC in contentFiles
2. Try uploading to nuget.org

### Expected Behavior

Do not validate C++ pdbs

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Error NU3003: Package 'xunit 2.5.0' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The package signature is invalid or cannot be verified on this platform." (#12760) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

MSBuild version = "17.2.0+41abc5629"

### Worked before?

worked with xunit 2.4.2

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Updated the xunit package from 2.4.2 to the latest 2.5.0 (https://www.nuget.org/packages/xunit.core/2.5.0)
2. Queued a new build on our pipeline and nuget restore fails with the below error on windows only, restore is successful on mac and linux: error NU3003: Package 'xunit.runner.visualstudio 2.5.0' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The package signature is invalid or cannot be verified on this platform.
3. Below id the ado results with verbose logs:
https://mssqltools.visualstudio.com/CrossPlatBuildScripts/_build/results?buildId=206872&view=logs&j=b2ceb7fa-76eb-5e2f-7afb-5c7fcf0ef065&t=e83f30b7-a2bb-5f3b-7eb9-2f82380d0d78

### Verbose Logs

```shell
https://mssqltools.visualstudio.com/CrossPlatBuildScripts/_build/results?buildId=206872&view=logs&j=b2ceb7fa-76eb-5e2f-7afb-5c7fcf0ef065&t=e83f30b7-a2bb-5f3b-7eb9-2f82380d0d78&l=5
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Paulnsac helm datree" (#12759) at NuGet/Home
Opened pull request "Paulnsac patch 3" (#12758) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "NUGET_PACKAGES, NUGET_HTTP_CACHE_PATH, NUGET_SCRATCH and NUGET_PLUGINS_CACHE_PATH not working" (#12756) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

17.3.1

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Install the nuget package Microsoft.Build version 17.3.1
Load a csproj using an instance of Microsoft.Build.Evaluation.Project
Run the method Build of the instance
We get the following exception:
```
Project "C:\EpicorData\Users\epicor\UD\Source\Shared\Contracts\UD\CPQOrderDtl_c\Erp.Contracts.UD.CPQOrderDtl_c.csproj" (default targets):

C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\6.0.405\Sdks\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\targets\Microsoft.PackageDependencyResolution.targets(267,5): error NETSDK1004: Assets file 'C:\EpicorData\Users\epicor\UD\Source\Shared\Contracts\UD\CPQOrderDtl_c\obj\project.assets.json' not found. Run a NuGet package restore to generate this file.
Done building project "Erp.Contracts.UD.CPQOrderDtl_c.csproj" -- FAILED.
```
This runs on an IIS App pool that runs using the user Network Service, that runs in a Windows container running with the security context of a gMSA.
If we change the IIS App pool to run using the System user, we're able to build the project.
We're also able to build the project if we give the Network Service user access to the app data directory of the System user which is c:\windows\system32\config\systemprofile

We're trying to get away from giving the Network service access to the system user app data directory and instead rely on the NUGET_* environment variables in order to redirect temporary files into a folder that we already gave the Network service user access to.
What we did to give the Network service user visibility over the NUGET_* environment variables was to set the environment variables of the Network Service SID via a registry change.
```
New-PSDrive HKU Registry HKEY_USERS
New-ItemProperty -Path "HKU:\S-1-5-20\Environment" -Name "NUGET_PACKAGES" -Value "C:/storage/nuget-packages" -PropertyType String -Force
New-ItemProperty -Path "HKU:\S-1-5-20\Environment" -Name "NUGET_HTTP_CACHE_PATH" -Value "C:/storage/nuget-http-cache" -PropertyType String -Force
New-ItemProperty -Path "HKU:\S-1-5-20\Environment" -Name "NUGET_SCRATCH" -Value "C:/storage/nuget-scratch" -PropertyType String -Force
New-ItemProperty -Path "HKU:\S-1-5-20\Environment" -Name "NUGET_PLUGINS_CACHE_PATH" -Value "C:/storage/nuget-plugins-cache" -PropertyType String -Force
```

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet list package errors with Object reference not set to an instance of an object" (#12755) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

all?

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

On very rare occasions (although somehow our CI test `DotnetListPackageTests.ListPackage_WithHttpSource_Warns` is hitting it very frequently), `dotnet list package`, with one of the arguments that makes HTTP requests (`--outdated`, `--vulnerable`, or `--deprecated`) will output a NullReferenceException message, followed by the help message

> error: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
> 
> Usage: NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat.dll package list [arguments] [options]



### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Improve hashing and equality allocations/performance" (#12746) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet.Client has a bunch of redundant allocations in the computation of equality and hash codes.

It should be possible to avoid a lot of `OrderBy` calls in `GetHashCode` calls to `HashCodeCombiner` by using XOR on unordered items.

The `NoAllocEnumerate` method can be improved for `IList<T>` to never allocate a fallback enumerator.

Calls to `HashCodeCombiner.CheckInitialized` can be removed, as more modern C# allows field initializers on structs.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Show a Visual Studio notification when a vulnerability is detected" (#12399) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### The Elevator Pitch

In addition to #12398, a notification should appear in Visual Studio's notification center with a link to the package manager UI to address issues.

The notification will let the user know what package in what project/solution is vulnerable or its plural equivalent. i.e. `Known security vulnerabilities have been detected in your project(s)/solution`.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1288848/215889414-0cf1c648-0149-4958-a223-5c25a575020e.png)


### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug Bash] No warning info shows when adding a package pattern with a long string which is more than maximum length characters in the “Add New Package Source Mapping” dialog" (#12742) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

NuGet Client Dev\6.8.0.22

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

None

### Repro Steps & Context

VS Version: Main\33912.166
NuGet Version: Dev\6.8.0.22
OS Version: Windows-11-Enterprise-22H2 ENU
#### Repro Steps:
1.	Open VS, click menu File->New Project, create a Console App (.Net Core) project.
2.	Right-Click the project in the Solution Explorer window and select ‘Manage NuGet Packages…’.
3.	Click the “settings” button on the right panel and click “Package Source Mapping” tab.
4.	Click “Add” button and type a long string which is more than maximum length characters.
#### Expected:
There should be a warning info to tell user the maximum length of the string.
#### Actual:
No warning info shows as below.
![image](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/assets/20632625/dfe330c0-b50d-489f-a799-27578ffc3343)
#### Notes:
It is not a regression since it is a new feature.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Test Failures in package signing code when executed on .NET 5 master" (#9509) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Package signing branch has few new entries defined in [build/config.props](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev-feature-xplatVerification/build/config.props#L40-L49) to define `dotnet` cli version for building and running tests. Updated `CliVersionForBuilding` .NET SDK version to .NET 5 latest stable preview release and `CliVersionForTesting` to `master` to test using latest release.

[Link to CI Build](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3692054&view=results) for the [PR](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3372)

* Windows (IsCore)
  * PackCommand_PackSolution_AddsProjectRefsAsPackageRefs
  * PackCommand_PackLicense_IncludeLicenseFileWithSnupkg
  * PackCommand_PackLicense_IncludeLicenseFileWithSymbolsNupkg
  * PackCommand_PackProject_AddsProjectRefsAsPackageRefs
  * PackCommand_PackNewDefaultProject_IncludeBuildOutputDoesNotCreateLibFolder
  * PackCommand_PackNewDefaultProject_InstallPackageToOutputPath
  * PackCommand_PackProjectWithPackageType_SnupkgContainsOnlyOnePackageType
  * PackCommand_PackNewDefaultProject_IncludeSymbolsWithSnupkg
  * PackCommand_PackNewDefaultProject_NupkgExists
  * PackCommand_PackNewDefaultProject_BuildOutputTargetFolderOutputsLibsToRightFolder
  * PackCommand_PackEmbedInteropPackage

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2023-29337 | NuGet Client Remote Code Execution Vulnerability" (#69) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: # Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2023-29337 | NuGet Client Remote Code Execution Vulnerability ## Executive summary Microsoft is releasing this security advisory to provide information about a vulnerability in .NET and NuGet on Linux. This advisory also provides guidance on what developers can do to update their applications to remove this vulnerability. A vulnerability exists in .NET 6.0, .NET 7.0 and NuGet(nuget.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement) where a potential race condition that can lead to a symlink attack on Linux. Non-Linux platforms are not affected. ## Discussion Discussion for this issue can be found at https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/12653 ## Mitigation factors Microsoft has not identified any mitigating factors for this vulnerability. ## Affected software This issue only affects Linux systems. ### NuGet & NuGet Packages - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.6.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.5.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.4.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.3.2 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.2.3 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver, NuGet.PackageManagement 6.0.4 version or earlier. [GitHub Advisory](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/security/advisories/GHSA-6qmf-mmc7-6c2p) ### .NET SDK(s) - Any .NET SDK 7.0.106 or earlier, or 7.0.303 or earlier - Any .NET SDK 6.0.117 or earlier, or 6.0.312 or earlier, or 6.0.409 or earlier. ### How do I know if I am affected? If you have a NuGet package or .NET SDK with a version listed in [affected software](#affected-software), you're exposed to the vulnerability. ### How do I fix the issue? To fix the issue, please install the latest version of .NET 6.0 or .NET 7.0 and NuGet (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Protocol, NuGet.Common, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.PackageManagement versions). If you have installed one or more .NET SDKs through Visual Studio, Visual Studio will prompt you to update Visual Studio, which will also update your .NET SDKs. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.6.0 or lower, you should download and install 6.6.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.6.1/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.5.0 or lower, you should download and install 6.5.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.5.1/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.4.1 or lower, you should download and install 6.4.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.4.2/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.3.2 or lower, you should download and install 6.3.3 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.3.3/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.2.3 or lower, you should download and install 6.2.4 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.2.4/nuget.exe. - If you're using NuGet.exe 6.0.4 or lower, you should download and install 6.0.5 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.0.5/nuget.exe. You can get the version of NuGet.exe by running the `nuget` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` NuGet Version: 6.0.0.280 usage: NuGet [args] [options] Type 'NuGet help ' for help on a specific command. To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://www.nuget.org/downloads ``` You can list the versions you have installed by running the `dotnet --info` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` .NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json): Version: 6.0.300 Commit: 8473146e7d Runtime Environment: OS Name: Windows OS Version: 10.0.18363 OS Platform: Windows RID: win10-x64 Base Path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\6.0.300\ Host (useful for support): Version: 6.0.5 Commit: 8473146e7d .NET Core SDKs installed: 6.0.300 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk] .NET Core runtimes installed: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App] Microsoft.NETCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App] Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App] To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://aka.ms/dotnet-download ``` - If you're using .NET 7.0, you should download and install Runtime 7.0.7 or SDK 7.0.107 or SDK 7.0.304 from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/7.0. - If you're using .NET 6.0, you should download and install Runtime 6.0.18 or SDK 6.0.118 or SDK 6.0.312 from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/6.0. Once you have installed the updated runtime or SDK, restart your apps for the update to take effect. Additionally, if you've deployed self-contained applications targeting any of the impacted versions, these applications are also vulnerable and must be recompiled and redeployed. ## Other Information ### Reporting Security Issues If you have found a potential security issue in .NET 6.0 or .NET 7.0, please email details to secure@microsoft.com. Reports may qualify for the Microsoft .NET Core & .NET 5 Bounty. Details of the Microsoft .NET Bounty Program including terms and conditions are at . ### Support You can ask questions about this issue on GitHub in the .NET GitHub organization. The main repo is located at https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client . The Announcements repo will contain this bulletin as an issue and will include a link to a discussion issue. You can ask questions in the linked discussion issue. ### Disclaimer The information provided in this advisory is provided "as is" without warranty of any kind. Microsoft disclaims all warranties, either express or implied, including the warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. In no event shall Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers be liable for any damages whatsoever including direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, loss of business profits or special damages, even if Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers have been advised of the possibility of such damages. Some states do not allow the exclusion or limitation of liability for consequential or incidental damages so the foregoing limitation may not apply. ### Acknowledgements [Kalle Niemitalo](https://github.com/KalleOlaviNiemitalo) ### External Links [CVE 2023-29337](https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2023-29337) ### Revisions V1.0 (June 13, 2023): Advisory published. _Version 1.0_ _Last Updated 2023-06-13_
